nodes.text: A decision tree-based machine learning model can classify and predict diabetes status of patients using the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset
Diabetes is a prevalent global health problem with rising incidence and mortality, motivating automated diagnostic tools
We implemented a binary decision tree classifier using Python (Pandas, Scikit-learn) in the Spyder environment to build the diagnostic model
The Pima Indians Diabetes DataBase (768 instances, 9 attributes) was used as the dataset to train and test the decision tree model
Data preprocessing removed rows with implausible zero values for Glucose, BloodPressure and BMI (35 samples) before model training
The model training procedure: load data, split into training and testing sets, train DecisionTreeClassifier, predict, compute accuracy, classification report, confusion matrix, and visualize the tree
Decision tree split criteria considered include entropy, Gini index and classification error as measures of node heterogeneity and information gain
Three experiments were performed with different train/test splits: 70/30, 50/50 and 30/70
Experimental results show varying accuracy depending on train/test split; the best reported accuracy among experiments was 0.71 for the 50% training / 50% testing split
An observed pattern in these experiments is interpreted as: allocating more data for training generally improves the accuracy estimate
Feature inspection indicates some attributes have greater impact on classification and some features contain outliers requiring cleaning, which affects classifier performance

Conclusion: Decision tree analysis is a viable predictive modeling tool for diabetes classification with fast learning, intuitive rule generation, nonparametric modeling and competitive prediction accuracy; for this study the 50/50 split yielded accuracy 0.71
Limitation: Model outputs require subsequent clinical consultation and more accurate diagnosis by a doctor; some dataset features may be unavailable to users, reducing practical system value
